title: Researchers teach an AI to write better chart captions
summary: Researchers at MIT have developed a dataset called VisText to improve automatic captioning systems for charts. Chart captions are important for helping readers understand and retain data, particularly for those with visual disabilities. Autocaptioning techniques can help alleviate the labor-intensive process of writing detailed captions, but they often struggle to provide additional context. The MIT researchers found that machine-learning models trained with their dataset consistently generated precise and semantically rich captions that described data trends and complex patterns. The goal is to provide VisText as a tool for researchers to improve chart autocaptioning systems and enhance accessibility for people with visual disabilities. The dataset contains over 12,000 charts represented as data tables, images, and scene graphs, along with associated captions. The researchers trained machine-learning models using different representations and combinations of representations, finding that models trained with scene graphs performed as well or better than those trained with data tables. They also trained models with low-level and high-level captions separately to vary the complexity of the content. The researchers conducted a qualitative examination of the captions produced by their best-performing method and categorized common errors. They also highlighted the ethical considerations of autocaptioning systems, as generative machine-learning models can sometimes provide incorrect or misleading information. The researchers plan to optimize the models, expand the dataset, and gain insights into what the autocaptioning models are learning about chart data.
